item.title: Hobbies
item.description:
Music

I enjoy exploring the world by listening to a variety of music genres, with indie-pop, alternative rock, and jazz hip-hop being my favorites. Here’s a playlist of 10 songs that best capture my musical personality: JZ’s Playlist.

I can also play several instruments, including acoustic guitar, bass, drums, and the guzheng, a traditional Chinese instrument.

Sports

I play tennis and pickleball, and I also love watching tennis matches. I admire the players’ mindset and mental resilience during games. Some of my favorite players are Qinwen Zheng, Iga Swiatek, Coco Gauff, and Rafa Nadal.

item.title: Publications
item.description:
2024

Yang, X., Li, T., Chen, T., Zheng, J., & Li, W. Incorporation of Al into diatom frustule as a proxy of seawater Al/Si ratios in the Antarctic Zone of the Southern ocean: Implications for surface silicic acid concentrations during the last glacial period. < Quaternary Science Reviews > URL

2023

Chen, T., Zheng, J., Li, T., Shi, X., Robinson, L. F., Wang, M., Li, G., Ling, H., Ren, X., & Ji, J. Thorium isotope evidence for glacial–interglacial dust storminess and productivity in the North Pacific gyre. < Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta > URL

item.title: Researches
item.description:
My current works focus on:

Variations of the Pacific ocean during orbital and millennial climate changes.

  • Quantifying the lithogenic dust flux input to the ocean by U-Th isotopes.
  • Reconstruction of paleo ocean circulation by Pa/Th.
  • Exploring the impact of iron-fertilization on marine productivity.

The burial mechanisms of elements at the seawater-sediment interface.

  • Looking into the budgets and burial mechanisms of various elements (such as: Si, Fe, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) to the seafloor.
  • Investigating the kinetics of solute transportation at the seafloor through constraints from U-Th isotopes.

Published Works

A cool method to measure the U-Th-Pa concentrations in marine sediments

Hi there, I’m Jianfan, Welcome to my site!

I’m a PhD student of marine geochemistry.

Growing up during a time when environmental issues are becoming an increasingly urgent global concern, I’ve long been curious about why and how our planet is facing these challenges. I chose marine geochemistry as my undergraduate major because of this interest and am now pursuing a career in research.

Currently, I’m working on my PhD project at Nanjing University, studying past variations in dust input and productivity in the North Pacific ocean under the guidance of my mentor, Prof. Tianyu Chen. I hope my research can offer insights into future climate change and contribute to make our planet great again.
